Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to support a 1.5 day workshop for potential users of the newly created PhantomNet Mobile Testbed, that is being supported by an NSF CISE Research Infrastructure (CRI) Community Infrastructure Award. This workshop will be held on the campus of the University of Utah in fall 2014. PhantomNet is a testbed facility aiming to enable research and teaching at the intersection of mobile networking, cloud computing and software defined networking. PhantomNet leverages the time-tested Emulab testbed control stack and is integrated with the Emulab instance at the University of Utah. There are two primary goals for the workshop. The first is to provide potential users of the facility with hands-on exposure to the testbed to enable them to understand how PhantomNet can be used in their research and teaching. The second is to garner input from the target user community about the desired functionality of the testbed to enable the PhantomNet team to prioritize development tasks for the remainder of the project.

As it is freely and remotely available to all academic institutions, the hands-on teaching that PhantomNet enables as part of this workshop is expected to better equip teachers and students alike in domains that are critically important to modern society. In addition, getting input from the user community relatively early in the development of the facility will help the PhantomNet team adjust their development priorities to better serve the community needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary purpose of this award was to host a workshop at the University of Utah for potential users of the PhantomNet Mobile Testbed. PhantomNet is a testbed facility, being developed by the Flux Research Group at the University of Utah, aiming to enable research and teaching at the intersection of mobile networking, cloud computing and software defined networking.
The workshop had two goals: First to provide potential users of the facility with hands-on exposure to the testbed to enable them to understand how PhantomNet can be used in their research and teaching. Second to garner input from the target user community about the desired functionality of the testbed to enable the PhantomNet team to prioritize development tasks for the testbed.
In addition to the above primary goal, the award also enabled the PhantomNet team to undertake outreach activities, in the form of hands-on tutorials, to potential users of the testbed.  
A successful PhantomNet Users’ Workshop was held at the University of Utah in February 2015. The workshop was instrumental in establishing the needs of testbed users and in prioritizing development effort on the testbed. 
The material used during the workshop was further developed into tutorial material which was presented at more than six tutorials associated with networking conferences and workshops.
PhantomNet is a unique mobile networking research infrastructure. The award allowed potential testbed users to be made aware of the infrastructure, thus enabling the advancement of research and teaching in the domains of mobile networking, cloud computing and software defined networking.
